Miyako wants to make a model of the Great Pyramid of Giza. Her model will be in 
the shape of a square pyramid. Which of the nets shown can she use to make her 
model? How do you know?
Net A
Net B
Net C

lessons.title:
Use Nets to Find Surface Area
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to find a 
net for a three-dimensional figure.
	
Look at the first Analyze It. How does reasoning help you find the correct net?
	
Which of the nets can Miyako use to make her model? How does the table help 
you choose a net that can be used to make the pyramid?
	
The nets at the right each have one square and four 
identical triangles. A student says that both nets can 
be used to form a pyramid. Do you agree? Explain.
	
How do the number and arrangement of the shapes in a net relate to the 
corresponding three-dimensional figure?
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand nets.

lessons.title:
Use Nets to Find Surface Area
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to find 
the surface area of a three-dimensional figure.
	
Look at the Picture It. Two line segments in the net are labeled 5 ft. Where do you 
see these line segments in the prism?
	
The length of one line segment in the net is labeled 6 ft. Which other line 
segments in the net could be labeled 6 ft? How do you know?
	
Aisha wrote the expression 2​1 ​

lessons.title:
Use Nets to Find Surface Area
Practice Finding the Surface Area of a  
Three-Dimensional Figure
	
➤Study the Example showing how to find the surface area of a  
three-dimensional figure. Then solve problems 1–5.
Example
Nina uses clay to make an earring in the shape of a  
square pyramid. She plans to cover the earring with  
glitter. What is the area Nina will cover with glitter?
Use a net to help you find the surface area of the pyramid.
The pyramid has five faces: one square base and  
four identical triangles. 
Find the sum of the areas of the faces.
	 18 • 18 1 4​1 ​

The Ramirez family is making tamales. They wrap the tamales in corn husks for 
steaming. They already have 8 corn husks. Isabel is bringing 3 bags of corn husks. 
Each bag has the same number of corn husks. 
How can you use an algebraic expression to show the total number of corn husks 
the Ramirez family will have after Isabel arrives?

Algebraic Expressions

lessons.title:
Work with Algebraic Expressions
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to write 
and interpret an algebraic expression.
	
Look at the algebra tiles in the first Model It. What do the small square tiles 
represent? What unknown quantity does each large rectangular tile represent?
	
Use the variable x to represent each large rectangular tile. What algebraic 
expression can you write to represent the situation?
 	
Gavin looks at the second Model It and uses the variable h to write the expression 
8 1 3h. How many terms does the expression have? Which term is a product? 
Identify the variable and the coefficient and explain what each represents.
	
Jade writes the expression for the total number of corn husks as 3c 1 8. 
Elias writes it as 8 1 c 1 c 1 c. Are both expressions correct? Explain.
 	
How can you write an algebraic expression to represent a situation in which there 
is an unknown quantity? 
 	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand how to solve the 
Try It problem.

lessons.title:
Work with Algebraic Expressions
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to 
interpret and evaluate an algebraic expression.
	
Look at the algebraic expression in Analyze It. How do you know that the 
coefficient of the term 6a represents the cost of an adult ticket?
	
How does the order of operations help you interpret the expression 6a 1 5c in 
Model It? Describe the order in which you perform the operations shown in the 
expression 6(2) 1 5(3).
	
The choices for the variables in Model It do not give a total cost of $38. Show that 
the value of 6a 1 5c is 38 when a 5 3 and c 5 4. What does this mean about the 
number of adult tickets and child tickets the Patel family buys? 
	
How is evaluating an algebraic expression similar to evaluating a numerical 
expression? How is it different? 
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand how to evaluate 
algebraic expressions.

In a video game, players start with a score of 100 points. 
They earn 8 points for each gold coin and 25 points for each 
gem they find. Isaiah finds 3 gold coins and 2 gems. Write and 
evaluate an algebraic expression to find Isaiah’s score. Use c for 
the number of gold coins found and g for the number of gems 
found. Show your work.
	
SOLUTION   
	
Aponi writes an algebraic expression to represent the product of 10 and the difference 
of 5y and 1. The factors of her expression are              and              .
	
Demi starts a gardening project with 80 sunflower seeds. She plants 12 of the 
seeds. Then she gives 5 seeds each to some friends. Which expression represents 
the number of sunflower seeds Demi has left after she gives seeds to f friends?
A	 80 2 12 2 ​ f 
·· 
5 ​	
	
B	 80 2 12 2 ​

Dear Family,
This week your student is learning how to evaluate expressions with exponents. 
Exponents are used to represent repeated multiplication. One way to show this is 
with a power. The base is the number you are multiplying. The exponent is the 
number of times the base is a factor.

lessons.title:
Write and Evaluate Expressions with Exponents
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to write 
and evaluate expressions with exponents.
	
Look at the tree diagram in the Picture It. How many dots would there be in 
a row for Hour 4? Explain.
	
Explain how to use the number of people shown by one row of the tree diagram 
to find the number people in the next row of the tree diagram.
	
Look at the table in Model It. Write the number of people who share the 
photo in the sixth hour as a power of 2. How many people share the photo in 
the sixth hour?
	
Alexis finds the value of 26 by writing 4 • 4 • 4. Xavier finds the value of 26 by 
writing 8 • 8. Why are both expressions ways to find 26?
	
Write the number of people who share the photo in Hour 9 as a power of 2. 
How do you know what number to use as the exponent?
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand how to solve the 
Try It problem.

lessons.title:
Write and Evaluate Expressions with Exponents
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand using the 
order of operations when evaluating expressions with exponents.
	
Look at the first Model It. Jayden evaluated the expression 4 1 32 by adding first 
to get 72. Use the order of operations to explain Jayden's error.
	
Place parentheses in the expression 4 1 32 so that the value of the expression is 72.
	
Evaluate 4 1 n2 when n 5 40. How many tiles are in Stage 40 of the pattern?
	
The expression 4 1 n2 represents adding 4 to a power. Now think about 
multiplying a power by 4.
a.	 Write 4 • n2 and (4 • n)2 without exponents.
b.	 Should you think of 4n2 as 4 • n2 or as (4n)2? Explain your reasoning.
	
Describe the order of operations you would use to evaluate 8 1 4(32).
	
How do exponents fit into the order of operations?
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand how to use order of 
operations to evaluate expressions with exponents.

Example
What is the value of the expression 4(5 2 2)2 1 53?
Use the order of operations to evaluate the expression.
Subtract inside the parentheses.	
4(5 2 2)2 1 53 5 4(3)2 1

lessons.title:
Add, Subtract, and Multiply Multi-Digit Decimals
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to add 
and subtract decimals.
	
Look at the first Model It. In the first place-value chart, why is the thousandths 
column for the decimal 5.67 empty?
	
Look at the second Model It. In the addition step, 5.67 is written as 5.670. 
Does this change the value of 5.67? Explain your reasoning.
	
Look at the subtraction step in the second Model It. Why is 8.1 rewritten as 8.100?
	
How much greater is the mass of a dollar coin than the combined masses of a 
dime and a quarter? How can you check that your answer is reasonable?
	
How are algorithms for addition and subtraction of decimals similar to algorithms 
for addition and subtraction of whole numbers? How are they different?
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand how to add and 
subtract decimals.

lessons.title:
Add, Subtract, and Multiply Multi-Digit Decimals
Practice Using the Standard Algorithm to 
Add and Subtract Decimals
	
➤Study the Example showing how to use the standard algorithm to add 
decimals. Then solve problems 1–5.
Example
Trinidad's house is 1.94 km from the library. The library is 0.347 km from the 
park. Trinidad walks from her house to the library and then from the library 
to the park. What is the total distance Trinidad walks?
Line up the decimals by place value. Write each decimal with the same number 
of decimal places. Then regroup as needed to add.
1.

lessons.title:
Add, Subtract, and Multiply Multi-Digit Decimals
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to 
multiply decimals.
	
Look at the first Model It. How are products of whole numbers used to find the 
product of 0.224 and 4.2?
	
Look at the second Model It. What is the sum of the partial products 448 and 
8,960? Where do you see this sum in the fraction form of the product?
	
Why does multiplying a decimal in the thousandths by a decimal in the tenths 
give a product in the ten-thousandths? 
	
What is the total amount of medicine the cat needs, written as a decimal? How do 
you know where to place the decimal point in the product? 
	
How can you use the algorithm for multiplying whole numbers when you 
multiply decimals? 
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand how to multiply decimals.

lessons.title:
Understand Rate Concepts
Model It: Two Rates for a Ratio Relationship
	
➤Try this problem about rates.
 	
You can write two rates for any ratio relationship.
a.	 In Aja’s city, all blocks are about the same length. It takes Aja 20 minutes to 
walk 5 blocks to the library. Complete the table of equivalent ratios to 
show Aja’s two rates.
b.	 Describe the rate that Aja walks in blocks per minute and  
in minutes per block.
c.	 Explain why Aja can use her rate in blocks per minute to estimate how 
many blocks she can walk in 45 minutes.
CONNECT IT
	
➤Complete the problems below.
	
Suppose Aja walks faster on her way home from the library. How will this change 
affect Aja’s rate in blocks per minute? Explain.
	
Use a model to show the snail’s rate in centimeters per minute and its 
rate in minutes per centimeter. Describe each rate in words.

lessons.title:
Understand Rate Concepts
	
An elevator in the Seattle Space Needle can rise 100 meters  
in 50 seconds. Use a model to show the elevator’s rate of travel in 
meters per second and in seconds per meter. Describe each rate 
in words.
	
Zahara rides with her dad to her grandmother’s house. They travel 159 miles  
in 3 hours. Her uncle, Jorge, drives there separately from his home.
a.	 At what speed does Zahara’s dad drive, in miles per hour? Draw a model to 
show your work.
	
	
SOLUTION   
b.	 Jorge’s trip takes the same amount of time as Zahara’s, but he travels a shorter 
distance. Does Jorge drive faster or slower than Zahara’s dad?
	
A store changes the cost of a package of batteries. Now customers pay more 
money for the same number of batteries. Did the cost per battery increase, 
decrease, or stay the same? Explain how you know.
lessons.gpt5_context:
# Grade 6 V1 - Lesson 15: Understand Rate Concepts
	
An elevator in the Seattle Space Needle can rise 100 meters  
in 50 seconds. Use a model to show the elevator’s rate of travel in 
meters per second and in seconds per meter. Describe each rate 
in words.
	
Zahara rides with her dad to her grandmother’s house. They travel 159 miles  
in 3 hours. Her uncle, Jorge, drives there separately from his home.
a.	 At what speed does Zahara’s dad drive, in miles per hour? Draw a model to 
show your work.
	
	
SOLUTION   
b.	 Jorge’s trip takes the same amount of time as Zahara’s, but he travels a shorter 
distance. Does Jorge drive faster or slower than Zahara’s dad?
	
A store changes the cost of a package of batteries. Now customers pay more 
money for the same number of batteries. Did the cost per battery increase, 
decrease, or stay the same? Explain how you know.

lessons.title:
Understand Rate Concepts
Refine Ideas About Rate Concepts
Apply It
	
➤Complete problems 1–5.
	
Apply Malcolm makes chicken rice soup with his grandmother. Their family 
recipe calls for 5 cups of chicken broth per cup of brown rice. How many cups of 
brown rice are needed for 20 cups of chicken broth? Explain how you know.
	
Analyze At a tea shop, a package of vanilla tea weighs 1 ounce and costs $2. 
Cinnamon tea is priced at 2 ounces per dollar. Use rates to show which tea is more 
expensive per ounce. Include a model in your response.
	
Critique A school laser printer prints 72 pages in 6 minutes. Alanna’s home 
printer prints twice as many pages in twice as many minutes. Alanna says her 
printer’s rate in pages per minute is two times the rate of the school printer. 
Do you agree or disagree? Explain.

lessons.title:
Understand Percents
Model It: Bar Models
	
➤Try these two problems involving percents.
	
A group of students is raising money for a trip to Washington, D.C. They use a 
model that looks like a thermometer to track their progress toward their goal. 
a.	 The line at 100% represents the students’ goal. What amount of money are 
the students trying to raise?
b.	 The shading between 0% and 10% shows that the students have reached 
10% of their goal. How much money have the students raised so far?
c.	 After 1 week, the students reach 50% of their goal. Shade the model to 
show how much money the students have raised.
d.	 Use your model to complete this sentence.
	
50% of $             is $             .
	
Another group of students is also raising $400 for the trip.
a.	 On Monday, the students reach 25% of their goal. Label and shade the 
bar model to show their progress.
0%
$

lessons.title:
Understand Percents
	
Ms. Hunter’s class is hanging 500 red lanterns around the 
school for Lunar New Year. Before lunch, the class hangs 
100 of the lanterns.
PART A  Draw a model to show what percent of 500 lanterns 
the class hangs before lunch. 
PART B  How many lanterns are left to hang? What percent of the lanterns are left 
to hang? Use your model in Part A to explain your answer.
	
Math Journal Choose one of the following percents: 25%, 40%, or 60%. Use a 
model and words to explain what that percent means. Write at least two fractions 
that represent your percent.

lessons.title:
Use Percents to Solve Problems
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to find 
the whole when a part and the percent are given.
	
Look at the double number line and the table in the Model Its. How do both 
models use the relationship between 40% and 10%?
	
How many miles make up 10% of the race? Explain how you know.
	
Suppose Akira completes 100% of the race. How many miles does he bike? 
Explain how you know.
	
Max used another method. First, he divided 24 mi by 8 to get 3 mi. Then he 
multiplied 3 mi by 20 to get 60 mi. What percent of the whole race is 3 mi? 
Why did Max multiply 3 mi by 20?
	
How can you find the whole when you know a part and the percent?
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you understand finding the whole when you 
know the part and the percent.

Practice Finding the Whole
	
➤Study the Example showing how to find the whole when a part and the 
percent are given. Then solve problems 1–5.
Example
Carmela saves $27. This is 30% of the money she earns.  
How much does Carmela earn?
You can use a double number line to find the whole when you know  
a part and the percent. On the number line, 27 lines up with 30%.  
To find the whole, find the number that lines up with 100%.

60% of all the votes. How many students vote in the election? Explain how you 
found your answer.

SOLUTION

the book. How many pages do they have left to read?  
Show your work.
	
SOLUTION

lessons.title:
Use Measures of Center and Variability to Summarize Data
Previously, you learned about measures of center and variability. In 
this lesson, you will learn about choosing appropriate measures to 
describe data.
	
➤Use what you know to try to solve the problem below.
Mr. Shen wants to know how long it typically takes a student in his class to get to school. 
Which measure of center do you think he should choose to represent the typical time?

### Session 1: Ask: How did you

- **Problems**: 0

## Instructional Context

lessons.title:
Use Measures of Center and Variability to Summarize Data
CONNECT IT
	
Look Back Which measure of center do you think Mr. Shen should choose to 
represent the typical travel time for a student? Explain your reasoning.
	
Look Ahead Mr. Shen gives his students some math problems. 
The dot plot shows the number of problems each student solves.
a.	 Find the median and the mean of the data set.
b.	 Describe the shape of the data distribution. Are there any outliers? 
c.	 Which measure of center is more affected by the skew of the distribution? Why?
d.	 Would you choose the mean or the median to represent the typical number of 
problems a student solves? Explain your reasoning.
	
Reflect How can the shape of a data distribution affect which measure of center 
you choose to describe the data?

lessons.title:
Use Measures of Center and Variability to Summarize Data
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to 
choose measures of center and variability.
	
Look at the values of the medians shown in Analyze It. Which team has the 
greater median? How is this relationship shown in the box plot?
	
Look at the IQRs in the table. An IQR of 17.5 is more than two times an IQR of 7.5. 
How is this relationship shown in the box plots? What does this tell you? 
	
How can you use the data to argue that the Green Team is more likely to win?
	
Look at the box plots. The line inside the box for the Pink Team lines up with the 
right-most point of the Green Team’s plot. How could you use this to support an 
argument that the Pink Team is more likely to win in a competition?
	
How can you choose measures of center and variability to describe data sets?
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand how to solve the 
Try It problem.

lessons.title:
Solve Problems Involving Scale
Dear Family,
This week your student is learning about scale drawings. In a scale drawing, 
the size of an original figure changes, but its shape does not change.
Here are some examples of scale drawings that you may be familiar with.
•  A floor plan is a scale drawing of the actual layout of space in a building.
•  A state road map is a scale drawing of the actual roads in the state.
Scale drawings are typically used when objects are either too small or too large to 
be shown at their actual sizes. Floor plans and maps are drawn smaller than actual 
size. Suppose a floor plan is drawn so that 1 inch on the floor plan represents an 
actual distance of 3 feet. For that floor plan, the scale is 1 in. to 3 ft.
Your student will be solving scale drawing problems like the one below.
The scale from an actual volcano to a drawing of the volcano is 50 m to  
5 cm. The height of the drawing of the volcano is 25 cm. How tall is the 
actual volcano?
	
➤ONE WAY to find the height is to use a double number line.

lessons.title:
Solve Problems Involving Scale
CONNECT IT
	
Look Back Which of the triangles could be the same shape as nA? Explain.
	
Look Ahead nD is a scale drawing, or a scale copy, of nA. A scale drawing of 
a figure is larger or smaller than the original figure but is identical in shape. The 
scale is the ratio between the side lengths of the original figure and the 
corresponding side lengths of the scale drawing. To make a scale drawing, you can 
multiply each length in the original figure by a scale factor to get the 
corresponding length in the scale drawing. You can think of the scale factor as a 
unit rate.
L
M

c.	 What is the value of x? Describe two different ways you can find it.
	
Reflect Yukio says the scale from nPQR to nLMN is 3 : 1. Is Yukio correct? 
Explain.

lessons.title:

An artist makes a scale drawing of a parallelogram-shaped 
sculpture. The scale is 10 cm on the drawing for every 8 m on  
the sculpture. What is the area of the scale drawing? Show  
your work.
	
SOLUTION   
	
On a map, each centimeter represents 50 m.
a.	 The area of a rectangular park on the map is 6 cm2. Tameka says that to find the 
area of the actual park, in square meters, she can multiply the area of the park 
on the map by 2,500. Do you agree? Explain.
b.	 The area of a square sports arena is 10,000 m2. What are the dimensions of the 
sports arena on the map? Show your work.
	
	
SOLUTION   
c.	 The area of a parallelogram on the map is 5 cm2. What is the area of the actual 
parallelogram? Explain why you can find the area without knowing the 
dimensions of the parallelogram.

area of the actual park, in square meters, she can multiply the area of the park

lessons.title:
Solve Problems Involving Scale
Apply It
	
➤Use what you learned to solve these problems.
	
A scale drawing of an apartment is drawn on 1-centimeter grid 
paper. The scale from the apartment to the drawing is 8 ft to 
1 cm. Draw another scale drawing of the apartment using a scale 
from the apartment to the new drawing of 4 ft to 1 cm. Justify 
why your drawing is accurate.
	
The scale drawing at the right is a four-square court from a plan of a park. 
The scale from the actual court to the drawing is 8 ft to 1 cm. Draw 
another scale drawing of the court using a scale from the actual court to 
the new drawing of 12 ft to 1 cm. Justify why your drawing is accurate.
	
The scale drawing at the right shows a sandbox on a playground. The scale from 
the playground to the drawing is 12 in. to 1 unit length. Draw another scale 
drawing of the sandbox so that the scale from the playground to the new 
drawing is 20 in. to 1 unit length. Justify why your drawing is accurate.

Adela paints a mural of the Statue of Liberty. She uses the scale  
3 ft to 1 ft from the actual statue to the mural. On Adela’s  
mural, how much wider is the Statue of Liberty’s mouth than  
her eye? Show your work.
	
SOLUTION   
	
The scale from a square park to a drawing of the park is 5 m to 1 cm. The actual 
park has an area of 1,600 m2. What is the area of the drawing of the park? 
Show your work.
	
SOLUTION   
	
Math Journal Jada will draw two scale drawings of the same object on 1-cm 
grid paper. Each centimeter will represent a greater distance in the second 
drawing than in the first. Jada claims that the lengths in the second drawing will 
be longer than the lengths in the first drawing. Do you agree? Give an example of 
a scale and a measurement to support your answer.

a scale and a measurement to support your answer.

lessons.title:
Represent Proportional Relationships 
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to 
interpret graphs of proportional relationships.
	
Look at the equation in the first Model It. How can you use it to find the cost of 
1 pound of peppers? Of 3.5 pounds of peppers?
	
Look at the graph in the second Model It. What do 1 pound and 3.5 pounds of 
peppers cost? How can you tell?
	
What does the point (0, 0) represent in this situation? Why is the point (0, 0) part of 
the graph of any proportional relationship?
	
What does the point (1, 3) tell you? 
	
Which point gives the unit rate, or constant of proportionality, in any graph of a 
proportional relationship? Explain.
	
How could you use the graph of a proportional relationship to find any ratio in the 
proportional relationship? Why does this work?
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand how to solve the 
Try It problem.

lessons.title:
Represent Proportional Relationships 
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to 
identify graphs of proportional relationships.
	
Is the relationship between cost and time proportional at either company? Explain.
	
How are the graphs representing Company A and Company B alike and different?
	
The graph for Company B does not pass through the origin. Why does that show 
the relationship between time and cost is not proportional?
	
The graph at the right shows the relationship between cost and time 
at Company C. How are the graphs for Company A and Company C 
alike and different?
	
Is the relationship between time and cost proportional at Company C? Explain.
	
The graph of a proportional relationship will always be a straight line that passes 
through the origin. Why?
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand how to decide if two 
quantities are in a proportional relationship.

lessons.title:
Solve Proportional Relationship Problems
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to solve 
problems that involve proportional relationships.
	
Look at the first Model It. How can you identify the constant of proportionality 
from a verbal description?
	
Look at the second Model It. Where is the constant of proportionality in each 
equation? How can you use it to find how much money each girl raises in 3 hours?
	
How much money do Francisca and Elizabeth raise together? You could use the 
equation m 5 (51 1 58)h to find the amount of money they raise together. Why?
	
You have identified constants of proportionality in tables, verbal descriptions, 
graphs, and equations. Why is it useful to know how to identify constants of 
proportionality in different representations of proportional relationships?
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand how to solve the  
Try It problem.

lessons.title:
Solve Proportional Relationship Problems
	
Neena uses hearing amplifiers to listen to a song. The song has a consistent 
beat. Neena counts 11 beats in 5 seconds. What is the constant of 
proportionality for the relationship of beats to minutes? Show your work.
	
SOLUTION   
	
Deyvi goes to a carnival with $20.00. He spends $2.00 to get in and the rest 
on ride tickets. Each ticket is $1.50. How many tickets does Deyvi buy?
A	 9 tickets
B	 12 tickets
C	 13 tickets
D	 14 tickets
Bruno chose C as the correct answer. How might he have gotten that answer?

lessons.title:
Understand Reasons for Rewriting Expressions
Model It
	
➤Complete the problem about writing equivalent 
numerical expressions.
	
The yearbook team uses the same page layout to design a 
page for each school club. The dimensions shown are in 
inches. Different team members think about the total area of 
the page in different ways.
a.	 Paulo thinks of the area of the page as the product 
of the total length and the total width. 
Complete Paulo’s expression.
	
(       1 3) • (4 1       )
b.	 Tamera thinks of the area of the page as the sum of the  
areas of the photo sections and the list sections.  
Complete Tamera’s expression. What does Tamera’s expression  
let you see about the page layout that Paulo’s expression does not?
	
5(4 1       ) 1       (4 1 6)
c.	 Emily thinks of the area of the page as the sum of the areas of the four separate 
sections. Write an expression that represents Emily’s way of thinking. What 
does Emily’s expression let you see about the page layout that neither Paulo’s 
nor Tamera’s expression does?

# Grade 7 V1 - Lesson 16: Understand Reasons for Rewriting Expressions
Model It
	
➤Complete the problem about writing equivalent 
numerical expressions.
	
The yearbook team uses the same page layout to design a 
page for each school club. The dimensions shown are in 
inches. Different team members think about the total area of 
the page in different ways.
a.	 Paulo thinks of the area of the page as the product 
of the total length and the total width. 
Complete Paulo’s expression.
	
(       1 3) • (4 1       )
b.	 Tamera thinks of the area of the page as the sum of the  
areas of the photo sections and the list sections.  
Complete Tamera’s expression. What does Tamera’s expression  
let you see about the page layout that Paulo’s expression does not?
	
5(4 1       ) 1       (4 1 6)
c.	 Emily thinks of the area of the page as the sum of the areas of the four separate 
sections. Write an expression that represents Emily’s way of thinking. What 
does Emily’s expression let you see about the page layout that neither Paulo’s 
nor Tamera’s expression does?

lessons.title:
Understand Reasons for Rewriting Expressions
Model It: Algebraic Expressions
	
➤Try these two problems involving rewriting algebraic 
expressions to represent a situation.
	
Arturo’s family hires 3 painters. Each painter charges $60 per 
hour. Arturo’s family represents the charge for x hours of 
painting in different ways.
a.	 Arturo’s mom represents the situation with the expression 
60x 1 60x 1 60x. What does 60x represent? What  
does 60x 1 60x 1 60x represent?
b.	 Arturo’s dad represents the situation with the expression 180x. What does  
180x represent?
c.	 What information is in 60x 1 60x 1 60x that is not in 180x? What information is 
in 180x that is not in 60x 1 60x 1 60x?
	
Arturo writes the expression 480d 1 480d 1 480d to show how much the 
painters charge for d days of painting. Then he writes the equivalent 
expression 1,440d. What information is in 480d 1 480d 1 480d that is not 
in 1,440d? What information is in 1,440d that is not in 480d 1 480d 1 480d?

60x 1 60x 1 60x. What does 60x represent? What  
does 60x 1 60x 1 60x represent?
b.	 Arturo’s dad represents the situation with the expression 180x. What does  
180x represent?
c.	 What information is in 60x 1 60x 1 60x that is not in 180x? What information is 
in 180x that is not in 60x 1 60x 1 60x?
	
Arturo writes the expression 480d 1 480d 1 480d to show how much the 
painters charge for d days of painting. Then he writes the equivalent 
expression 1,440d. What information is in 480d 1 480d 1 480d that is not 
in 1,440d? What information is in 1,440d that is not in 480d 1 480d 1 480d?

with two variables.
	
Elu buys 3 adult and 3 child bus passes for a trip. The cost 
of an adult pass is a. The cost of a child pass is c.

expression represents the total cost of the six bus passes.

is in DeAndre’s expression that is not in his mother’s? What information is in his 
mother’s expression that is not in DeAndre’s?

t • 2 • 365 to represent how many minutes she spends brushing her teeth each

lessons.title:
Understand Reasons for Rewriting Expressions
Practice Representing a Situation with Different 
Expressions
	
➤Study how the Example shows that equivalent expressions can provide 
different information about a situation. Then solve problems 1–3.
Example
For the science fair, Ms. Patel orders one posterboard and one pack of  
stick-on letters for each student. Each posterboard costs $3. Each pack of 
stick-on letters costs $4. Ms. Patel represents the cost for x students with the 
expression x(3 1 4). Then she represents the cost with the equivalent 
expression 7x. What information does each expression tell you about 
the situation?
The expression x(3 1 4) tells you the cost of one posterboard and one stick-on 
letter pack. It shows you how both the posterboard and the stick-on letter pack 
contribute to the total cost.
The expression 7x tells you that the cost per student is $7. 
	
a.	 Mr. Gordon works with Ms. Patel from the Example. Mr. Gordon writes the 
expression 3x 1 4x to represent the cost of ordering posterboards and stick-on 
letters for x students. What information does 3x 1 4x tell you about the 
situation that the other expressions do not?
b.	 Suppose Mr. Gordon wants to buy 3 extra posterboards and 5 extra packs of 
stick-on letters. Write an expression that represents the cost of buying supplies 
for x students in addition to 3 extra posterboards and 5 extra packs of letters. 
Explain how your expression represents the new situation.

lessons.title:

Apply It
	
➤Complete problems 1–5.
	
Interpret Two people describe a regular polygon. Brianna says that the 
polygon has side length 6.3 cm and perimeter 31.5 cm. Desiderio says the polygon 
has side length n and perimeter 5n. Which person’s description tells you how 
many sides the polygon has without doing any calculations? Why?
	
Evaluate A company sells rectangular pools. The length of each pool is 2 times 
the width, w. Jelani represents the perimeter of a pool to a customer as 6w. Akiko 
represents the perimeter with the expression 2(2w 1 w). Explain what information 
each expression tells a customer.
	
Analyze The spirit club uses fabric to make school  
flags for students to wave at a pep rally. The club  
members want to find the amount of purple striped  
fabric, in square inches, that they need for one flag.  
Avery says they can use the expression 5(4) 1 7(4).  
Pedro says they can use the expression (12 • 8) 4 2.  
Explain why both students are correct.

lessons.title:
Understand Multi-Step Equations
Model It
	
➤Complete the problems about using reasoning to solve equations.
	
Instead of using a diagram, another way to solve an equation is to reason  
about its terms. Think about the equation 4w 1 8 5 32.
a.	 You can think of 4w as the unknown quantity. How could you find the  
value of 4w? What is the value of 4w?
b.	 How could you use the value of 4w to find the value of w? What is the 
value of w?
c.	 How can you check that the value of w is correct?
	
Think about the equation 4w 2 8 5 32.
a.	 The value of 4w is 40. How do you know this is true?
b.	 The value of w is 10. How do you know this is true?
	
Reflect How is reasoning about the value of y the same in 5y 1 10 5 25 and  
5y 2 10 5 25? How is it different?

lessons.title:
Understand Multi-Step Equations
Practice Reasoning About Multi-Step Equations
	
➤Study how the Example shows using reasoning to find the value of an 
unknown in an equation. Then solve problems 1–6.
Example
The product of 4 and (3 1 x) is equal to 36. What is the value of x?
The equation 4(3 1 x) 5 36 models this statement.
Think: 4 times what number is 36?
Since 4 • 9 equals 36, that means (3 1 x) equals 9.
Since 3 1 x 5 9, and 3 1 6 5 9, that means x equals 6.
	
The sum of twice a number, n, and 14 is 30. Write an equation that models this 
statement. Then explain how you might use reasoning to find the value of n.
 	
Is the value of (y 1 6) greater in 4(y 1 6) 5 48 or 12(y 1 6) 5 48?  
How do you know?
	
Ana wants to place 11 plants on 3 shelves. Each shelf holds the same number 
of plants, p. There are 2 plants that do not fit. Model this situation with an 
equation and a hanger diagram.

lessons.title:
Solve Problems Involving Percents
Previously, you learned how to find the percent of a number. 
In this lesson, you will learn about solving problems that 
involve percents.
	
➤Use what you know to try to solve the problem below.
Last year, a middle school band had 80 students. This year, 
the band has 120% of that number of students. How many 
students are in the band this year?
Explore Percents
LESSON 20 | SESSION

lessons.title:
Solve Problems Involving Area and Surface Area
Math 
Tools
Geometry 
Tool
Scientific 
Calculator
Lesson Title
Dear Family,
This week your student is learning how to use area and surface area to solve 
a variety of problems.
Some figures are made up of two or more other shapes, such as rectangles, 
squares, and triangles. One way to find the area of a figure like this is to find the 
area of those other shapes and add the areas together. In places where shapes 
overlap, you can make adjustments so that no area is added more than once.
The surface area of a three-dimensional figure is the sum of the areas of all its faces. 
You can find the surface area of any prism by finding the area of each face and then 
adding the areas. Your student will be solving problems like the one below.
What is the area of the figure at the right?
4 cm
2 cm
3 cm
	
➤ONE WAY to find the area is to decompose the figure into a 
triangle and a rectangle.
Area of rectangle: 4 • 3 5

lessons.title:
Find Unknown Angle Measures
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to find 
an unknown angle measure.
	
Look at Analyze It. What is another set of three angles that form a straight angle? 
What is another pair of vertical angles?
	
What is the value of x?
	
Explain how you can use straight angles to find m/TPV.
	
Explain how you can find m/TPV using the fact that vertical angles have 
equal measures.
	
The figure at the right shows two lines that intersect to form 
four angles. Use the figure to explain why vertical angles 
have the same measure.
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand how to find an 
unknown angle measure.

lessons.title:
Understand Dilations and Similarity
Model It
	
➤Complete the problems about dilating a figure.
	
A dilation may change a figure’s size. In a dilation, corresponding angles are 
congruent and corresponding side lengths are related by the same scale factor.
Complete the table to determine whether figures Q, R, and S are dilations of figure P.
R
Q P
S
	
The point from which a figure is dilated is called the center of 
dilation. A center of dilation can be inside, on, or outside 
a figure.
a.	 Use a straightedge to draw rays from the center of dilation 
through each set of corresponding vertices of figures R, P, 
and S.
	
For two figures,
	
•  If the figures are dilations of each other, then you can draw rays from the 
center of dilation through each pair of corresponding vertices.
	
•  If at least one pair of corresponding vertices do not lie on the same ray 
drawn from the center of dilation, then neither figure is a dilation of 
the other.
b.	 Can you draw rays from the point shown 
through each pair of corresponding vertices of 
figures R and Q?

lessons.gpt5_context:
# Grade 8 V1 - Lesson 4: Understand Dilations and Similarity
Model It
	
➤Complete the problems about dilating a figure.
	
A dilation may change a figure’s size. In a dilation, corresponding angles are 
congruent and corresponding side lengths are related by the same scale factor.
Complete the table to determine whether figures Q, R, and S are dilations of figure P.
R
Q P
S
	
The point from which a figure is dilated is called the center of 
dilation. A center of dilation can be inside, on, or outside 
a figure.
a.	 Use a straightedge to draw rays from the center of dilation 
through each set of corresponding vertices of figures R, P, 
and S.
	
For two figures,
	
•  If the figures are dilations of each other, then you can draw rays from the 
center of dilation through each pair of corresponding vertices.
	
•  If at least one pair of corresponding vertices do not lie on the same ray 
drawn from the center of dilation, then neither figure is a dilation of 
the other.
b.	 Can you draw rays from the point shown 
through each pair of corresponding vertices of 
figures R and Q?
	
Reflect Does a dilation change a figure’s shape? How is a dilation 
different from a translation, rotation, or reflection?

CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to 
perform a sequence of transformations involving dilations.
	
a.	 Look at Model It. Describe how the coordinates of the vertices change from 
nABC to the reflected figure nA9B9C9.  
b.	 Describe how the coordinates of the vertices change from nA9B9C9 to the 
dilated figure nA0B0C0. What are the coordinates of the vertices of nA0B0C0? 
	
a.	 Is nA9B9C9 similar to nABC? Is nA0B0C0 similar to nA9B9C9? Explain. 
b.	 Is nA0B0C0 similar to nABC? Explain.
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand how to perform 
sequences of transformations involving dilations.

describe sequences of transformations involving dilations.
	
Look at Picture It and Model It. Give the details of the transformations used in

the sequence? Explain.
	
What is another way you could map figure ABCD onto figure EFGH?
	
Suppose figure EFGH is the original figure and figure ABCD is the final image. What 
two transformations could you perform to map figure EFGH onto figure ABCD?
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand how to solve the  
Try It problem.

lessons.title:
Describe Angle Relationships
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to find 
and describe congruent angle relationships.
	
/WXO and /ZYO in the Try It problem are alternate interior angles. How can you 
tell? How do you know these angles are congruent?
	
Can you use a sequence of transformations to show that the pairs of alternate 
interior angles in this figure are congruent? Explain.
	
a.	 Alternate interior angles formed by parallel lines cut by a 
transversal are congruent. Mark the two pairs of alternate 
interior angles that are congruent. Then mark the vertical 
angles that are congruent. 
b.	 Name the pairs of alternate exterior angles in the figure. 
How are alternate exterior angles related when formed by 
parallel lines cut by a transversal? 
c.	 Name the pairs of corresponding angles in the figure. How are corresponding 
angles related when formed by parallel lines cut by a transversal?
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand the congruent angles 
formed by parallel lines cut by a transversal.

lessons.title:
Solve Linear Equations in One Variable
Previously, you learned how to solve one-variable equations.  
In this lesson, you will learn about solving one-variable equations  
that include fractions, decimals, the variable on both sides of the equation, 
and use of the distributive property.
	
➤Use what you know to try to solve the problem below.
Teresa is going with her family to watch professional barrel racers. Her family buys 
6 tickets. They have a coupon for $1.50 off each ticket. They pay $52.50 in total for 
their tickets. Write an equation that you could use to represent the situation. What 
is the price of a ticket before using the coupon?
Explore Linear Equations in One Variable
LESSON 10 | SESSION

their tickets. Write an equation that you could use to represent the situation. What 
is the price of a ticket before using the coupon?
Explore Linear Equations in One Variable
LESSON 10 | SESSION

lessons.title:
Solve Linear Equations in One Variable
CONNECT IT
	
Look Back What is the price of a ticket before using the coupon? What 
equation did you write? Explain what each part of the equation represents.
	
Look Ahead A linear equation in one variable can be written in the form  
ax 1 b 5 c, where b and c can be any numbers and a can be any number 
except zero.
a.	 Explain why 4(x 2 2.1) 5 7.2 is a linear equation in one variable.
b.	 The solution of a one-variable equation is the value of the variable that makes 
the equation true. What is the solution of 4(x 2 2.1) 5 7.2?
c.	 Look at the equation 4x 2 8.4 5 2x 1 5. The terms 4x and 2x are like terms 
because they are both written as a coefficient times x. To combine 4x and 2x, 
you can subtract 2x from both sides of the equation. Write the equation in the 
form ax 1 b 5 c. What is the solution of this equation?
d.	 Another way you can combine 4x and 2x is to subtract 4x from both sides 
of the equation. Write 4x 2 4x 2 8.4 5 2x 2 4x 1 5 in the form ax 1 b 5 c. 
What is the solution of this equation?
e.	 The original equation has the variable on both sides of the equation. 
What happens to the variable after combining the like terms?
	
Reflect Which way of combining like terms in problems 2c and 2d do you 
prefer? Explain.

lessons.title:
Solve Linear Equations in One Variable
	
Felipe counts this week’s food donations at a pet shelter. 
There are 16 full cases of canned food. There are 4 cases of 
canned food that are each missing 5 cans. Felipe records a 
total of 220 cans of food.
a.	 Use c to represent the number of cans in a full case. 
What expression could represent the number of cans in 
each case that is missing cans?
b.	 Write an equation you could use to find c.
c.	 How many cans are in a full case? How many cans are 
in each of the 4 other cases? Show your work. 
	
SOLUTION   
	
Five less than twice the value of a number is equal to three times the quantity of 
four more than one-half the number. What is the number? 
a.	 Let x be the number. Write and solve an equation to find x. Show your work. 
	
SOLUTION   
b.	 Does the solution of your equation solve the original problem? Explain.

lessons.title:
Determine the Number of Solutions to One-Variable Equations
CONNECT IT
	
Look Back What happened when you solved the equation? What happens 
when you substitute any number for x in the equation?
	
Look Ahead You know how to solve equations where you get a statement like 
x 5 5 or t 5 17.8. This means the equation is true for this one value of the variable. 
The equation has one solution. However, sometimes you solve an equation and 
get a statement like 32 5 32 or 0 5 0. This means the equation is true for any 
value of the variable. The equation has infinitely many solutions. 
a.	 Solve 5x 5 2. How many solutions does the equation have? Show your work.
b. 	Solve 9x 2 5 5 9x 2 5. How many solutions does the equation have? 
Show your work.
	
Reflect Look at the equation in problem 2b. How could you know that  
9x 2 5 5 9x 2 5 has infinitely many solutions without solving the equation?

lessons.title:
Determine the Number of Solutions to One-Variable Equations
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to write 
one-variable linear equations with different numbers of solutions.
	
Look at Analyze It. What must be true about the constant terms on each side of 
the equation if the equation has no solution? What must be true about the 
constant terms on each side of the equation if the equation has infinitely many 
solutions? How do you know?
	
a.	 Is there more than one number you could write on the line so the equation has 
no solution? Explain.
b.	 Is there more than one number you could write on the line so the equation has 
infinitely many solutions? Explain.
	
What constant term or x-term could you write on the line so the equation has 
exactly one solution? Is there more than one possibility? How do you know?
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand how to write  
one-variable linear equations with no solution, one solution, or infinitely  
many solutions.

lessons.title:
Solve Systems of Linear Equations Algebraically
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to use 
substitution to solve a system of equations.
	
Explain what v 5 4f 1 5 and v 1 f 5 30 tell you about the situation.
	
a.	 Look at both Model Its. You start with a system of two equations in two 
variables. In each case you end up with a single one-variable equation,  
4f 1 5 1 f 5 30 or 4f 1 5 5 2f 1 30. How does this happen? 
b.	 How many flower beds will there be in the garden? How many vegetable beds? 
Explain how you know.
	
a.	 Solve v 1 f 5 30 for f. Use this result to solve the system by substituting for f. 
	
b.	 When you solve a system of equations by substitution, does it matter which 
equation you solve for one variable or which variable you solve for? Explain.
	
Will substitution always work as a strategy to solve a system of equations? Explain.
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand how to solve the  
Try It problem.

lessons.title:

➤Explore different ways to solve systems of equations by elimination.
Amare buys museum souvenirs. He buys 3 animal figures and 6 bookmarks for $33. 
Later he returns 3 of the bookmarks for a refund. He buys 3 more animal figures and 
spends another $6. In the system of equations below, f is the price of each figure 
and b is the price of each bookmark.

# Grade 8 V1 - Lesson 13: Solve Systems of Linear Equations Algebraically
	
➤Explore different ways to solve systems of equations by elimination.
Amare buys museum souvenirs. He buys 3 animal figures and 6 bookmarks for $33. 
Later he returns 3 of the bookmarks for a refund. He buys 3 more animal figures and 
spends another $6. In the system of equations below, f is the price of each figure 
and b is the price of each bookmark.
	 3f 1 6b 5

lessons.title:
Solve Systems of Linear Equations Algebraically
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to use 
elimination to solve a system of equations.
	
Explain what 3f 1 6b 5 33 and 3f 2 3b 5 6 tell you about the situation.
	
a.	 Look at the first Model It. Why does the equation 6f 2 6b 5 12 have the same 
solutions as 3f 2 3b 5 6?
b.	 How does knowing that 6f 2 6b equals 12 allow you to add 6f 2 6b to one side 
and 12 to the other side of the equation 3f 1 6b 5 33?
c.	 How much does each figure cost? How much does each bookmark cost?
	
Solve the equation 0f 1 9b 5 27 in the second Model It for b. Do you get the 
same answer as you did in problem 2c?
	
How could you use substitution to find how much each figure and bookmark 
cost? When do you think you might choose to use substitution to solve a system 
instead of elimination?
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand how to solve the 
Try It problem.

lessons.title:
Solve Systems of Linear Equations Algebraically
CONNECT IT
	
➤Use the problem from the previous page to help you understand how to 
determine the number of solutions a system of equations has.
	
Look at the first Model It. What happens to the variables when you solve by 
either method? What kind of statements are 22 5 3 and 0 5 10? 
	
Look at the second Model It. What will the graph of this system look like? 
How many solutions does this system have? 
	
a.	 Solve this system of equations by either substitution or elimination. 
What happens to the variables? What result do you get? 
b.	 Write both equations in slope-intercept form. Compare slopes and y-intercepts. 
What will the graph of this system look like? How many solutions does this 
system have? 
c.	 Suppose the equations had different slopes. How many solutions would the 
system have? 
	
Suppose you solve a system of equations and both variables are eliminated. What 
do you know about the number of solutions the system has? Do you need to solve 
the system to find the number of solutions? Explain. 
	
Reflect Think about all the models and strategies you have discussed today. 
Describe how one of them helped you better understand how to determine 
when a system has no solution or infinitely many solutions.

lessons.title:
Apply Exponent Properties for Positive Integer Exponents
CONNECT IT
	
Look Back What is (103)2 rewritten as a single power? How did you get 
your answer?
	
Look Ahead An expression like (103)2 is called a power of a power. Recall that 
a power is an expression with a base and an exponent. You can write a power as 
repeated multiplication of the base when the exponent is a positive integer. 
The exponent tells how many times the base is used as a factor. For example, 
(23)2 5 (23) • (23).
a.	 Write 103 as a product of repeated factors. 
b.	 Square the expression you wrote in problem 2a. Write the answer as repeated 
multiplication. How does the number of repeated factors change?
c.	 Complete the table.
Power of 
a Power
Written as Repeated Factors
Single 
Power
(102)

original drop height does each ball reach after the third bounce?
